name: 王鏊
know_by_bio_summary: 王鏊（1450年—1524年），字濟之，號守溪，晚更號拙叟，学者称震泽先生，直隸蘇州府吳縣東洞庭山人，明朝正德、嘉靖年間重臣。官至戶部尚書、武英殿大學士，諡文恪。 王鏊之父王琬於成化九年（1473年），年五十五歲始授湖廣光化縣知縣，成化十三年（1477年）三月棄官歸里。王鏊自幼隨父讀書，善寫文章，國子監諸生爭誦其文。成化十年（1474年）甲午科應天鄉試第一名舉人（解元），成化十一年（1475年）聯捷乙未科會試第一名，一甲第三名進士（探花）。王鏊殿試原擬第一，一說因對策指陳時弊，為執政所忌；一說時任大學士商輅（明朝當時唯一連中三元者）不欲讓他人儷己，故抑之。授翰林院編修，歷侍講、右春坊右諭德、詹事府少詹事兼侍讀學士。弘治十三年（1500年）七月升吏部右侍郎，仍兼侍讀學士，正德元年（1506年）升吏部左侍郎，仍兼侍讀學士，十月與吏部尚書焦芳一同入閣參政，十二月升戶部尚書、文淵閣大學士、同知經筵事，正德二年（1507年）八月加少傅兼太子太傅、武英殿大學士，戶部尚書仍舊。 王鏊居官清廉，為人正直，時稱“天下窮閣老”。當時宦官劉瑾擅權，工部都水司郎中張瑋、雲南按察司副使姚祥、尚寶司卿顧璿被劉瑾荷杖幾死，王鏊怒斥劉瑾：“士可殺，不可辱。今辱且殺之，吾尚何顏居此。”與前戶部尚書韓文等上疏請誅劉瑾等“八黨”，不被採納，正德四年（1509年）四月致仕歸里，讀書著作，常與詩友遊山玩水，學者稱震澤先生。閒居十四年，嘉靖三年（1524年）卒，追贈太傅，諡文恪。 致仕後，在蘇州學士街天官坊建有“怡老園”，清朝改作江蘇布政使司衙門。 著有《詩文集》36卷、《奏疏》2卷、《守溪筆記》2卷、《震澤紀聞》2卷、《震澤長語》2卷、《震澤編》8卷、《姑蘇志》60卷、《春秋詞命》3卷、《本草單方》8卷，並參與纂修《明孝宗實錄》224卷。 祖王伯英，祖王惟道，父王朝用，官光化知县，皆以子贵，赠如其官。曾祖妣陆氏、祖妣叶氏、妣叶氏，皆一品夫人。 王鏊故里陸巷有惠和堂以及解元、會元、探花牌樓。其墓在東洞庭山梁家山。
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized:
A person born in 1450 and passed away in 1524, known by various names throughout his life, was a prominent figure during a certain dynasty's reign. He reached high-ranking positions such as Minister of Revenue and Grand Secretary. His father, at the age of fifty-five, was appointed as a county magistrate in a distant province but resigned a few years later. From a young age, this person studied under his father and excelled in writing, gaining recognition among his peers. In 1474, he achieved the top position in a provincial examination and continued to excel in subsequent national examinations, eventually becoming a distinguished scholar.

Despite being initially considered for the top position in a palace examination, political dynamics and rivalries affected his ranking. He was appointed to various prestigious roles, including editor and lecturer, and eventually rose to high ministerial positions. Known for his integrity and straightforwardness, he was respected as a principled official. During a period of political turmoil, he opposed a powerful eunuch and advocated for the removal of corrupt officials, but his petitions were not heeded. In 1509, he retired to his hometown, where he spent his time writing and enjoying nature with friends. He passed away in 1524 and was posthumously honored.

After retirement, he built a garden in his hometown, which later became a government office during another dynasty. He authored numerous works, including collections of poetry, essays, and historical records. His family lineage included several notable ancestors, and his ancestral home featured commemorative structures. His final resting place is located on a mountain near his birthplace.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The biography describes a scholar-official from the Ming Dynasty who was known for his integrity and scholarly achievements. The timeline and details such as his roles in government, his opposition to corrupt officials, and his post-retirement life of writing and enjoying nature align with the life of Zhu Xi, a prominent Confucian scholar. Zhu Xi was known for his contributions to Confucianism and his scholarly works, which fits the description of the individual's post-retirement activities. Additionally, the mention of a garden and his final resting place being commemorated aligns with Zhu Xi's legacy.

name: 张永
know_by_bio_summary: 張永（1465年—1529年），保定人。明武宗時的司礼监太监。 成化元年，出生。成化十一年，选入内廷。八虎之一，與劉瑾有怨懟，劉瑾打算將之黜發南京，於是兩人在皇帝面前對質。張永動手痛毆劉瑾，武宗令谷大用等置酒勸和。安化王朱寘鐇反叛，明武宗派楊一清總督寧夏、延綏，由張永任楊一清監軍。不久朱寘鐇被楊一清俘獲，張永趁獻俘時向武宗告發劉瑾罪狀，明武宗命令張永帶領禁軍捉拿劉瑾。最後劉瑾被殺。 正德十四年（1519年），寧王朱宸濠謀反，明武宗親征，命張永率邊兵兩千人為前鋒。王守仁將朱宸濠俘虜，交付張永。江彬欲誣王守仁謀反，被張永救解得免。明世宗即位後，八虎受到打擊，御史萧淮彈劾谷大用、丘聚等人蛊惑先帝，並牽連張永。世宗下诏命张永闲住。萧淮又弹劾张永在江西有违法事，贬为奉御，前往孝陵主持香光。嘉靖五年，召还京师。嘉靖六年，为御用监掌印太监。嘉靖八年（1529年），大学士杨一清等說張永實有功，遂起用掌管御用监，提督团营。不久死去。 [在维基数据编辑]
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized:
Zhang Yong (1465-1529), a native of Baoding, was a eunuch during the reign of Emperor Wuzong of the Ming Dynasty. Born in the first year of Chenghua, he was selected into the inner court in the eleventh year of Chenghua. As one of the Eight Tigers, he had grievances with Liu Jin, who planned to demote him to Nanjing, leading to a confrontation between the two before the emperor. Zhang Yong physically assaulted Liu Jin, and Emperor Wuzong ordered Gu Dayong and others to mediate over drinks. When Prince Anhua rebelled, Emperor Wuzong dispatched Yang Yiqing to oversee Ningxia and Yansui, with Zhang Yong supervising Yang Yiqing. Soon, Prince Anhua was captured by Yang Yiqing, and Zhang Yong took the opportunity to report Liu Jin's crimes to Emperor Wuzong, who then ordered Zhang Yong to lead the imperial guards to arrest Liu Jin. Eventually, Liu Jin was executed.

In the fourteenth year of Zhengde (1519), Prince Ning plotted rebellion, and Emperor Wuzong personally led a campaign, appointing Zhang Yong to lead two thousand border troops as the vanguard. Wang Shouren captured Prince Ning and handed him over to Zhang Yong. Jiang Bin attempted to falsely accuse Wang Shouren of treason, but Zhang Yong intervened to save him. After Emperor Shizong ascended the throne, the Eight Tigers were suppressed, and Censor Xiao Huai impeached Gu Dayong, Qiu Ju, and others for misleading the late emperor, implicating Zhang Yong. Emperor Shizong decreed Zhang Yong to retire. Xiao Huai further accused Zhang Yong of illegal activities in Jiangxi, resulting in his demotion to a minor official, tasked with overseeing incense offerings at Xiaoling. In the fifth year of Jiajing, he was recalled to the capital. In the sixth year of Jiajing, he became the chief eunuch of the Imperial Household Department. In the eighth year of Jiajing (1529), Grand Secretary Yang Yiqing and others acknowledged Zhang Yong's merits, leading to his appointment as the head of the Imperial Household Department and supervisor of the military camp. He passed away shortly thereafter.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The biography describes a historical figure from the Ming Dynasty who was a eunuch and part of the Eight Tigers, a group of powerful eunuchs during the reign of Emperor Wuzong. The individual had significant influence and was involved in political and military affairs, including the arrest and execution of Liu Jin, another prominent eunuch. The details about his involvement in suppressing rebellions and his eventual fall from power align with the historical figure Zhang Yong, who was indeed a notable eunuch during this period in Chinese history.
